questions.text: A 23y primigravida presents to the labor room at 38 weeks with labor pains. On examination, she is 9 cm dilated with the vertex at -3 station. An artificial rupture of membranes is done and immediately there is acute fetal distress. The umbilical cord is lying outside the introitus. Which of the following should not be done?

options.label: A
options.text: Immediately replace the cord back in the uterus

questions.correct_answer: A. Immediately replace the cord back in the uterus
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Immediately replace the cord back in the uterus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of umbilical cord prolapse, never attempt to replace the prolapsed cord back into the uterus . Instead, focus on measures to relieve pressure on the cord, such as positioning (Trendelenburg or knee-chest), administering tocolytics like Terbutaline, and monitoring cervical dilatation to expedite delivery when possible.
  • ➤ never attempt to replace the prolapsed cord back into the uterus

questions.text: A 34y woman presents with complaints of irregular cycles since 2 months. She says she is bleeding in between her usual cycles. She also has mild lower abdominal pain. She earlier had regular 28 day cycles. What is the next best step?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Urine pregnancy test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In women of reproductive age presenting with abnormal uterine bleeding, the first step is to rule out pregnancy using a urine pregnancy test (UPT) . This simple test is crucial to exclude pregnancy-related causes before proceeding with further investigations or treatment.
  • ➤ first step
  • ➤ urine pregnancy test (UPT)

questions.text: By doing McRoberts's manuever, how many shoulder dystocias get resolved?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 90%

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The McRoberts's maneuver is the first-line intervention in the management of shoulder dystocia and resolves 90% of cases by altering pelvic anatomy to facilitate delivery. It is essential to remember that it is the most effective and non-invasive initial maneuver for shoulder dystocia.
  • ➤ McRoberts's maneuver
  • ➤ 90%

questions.text: What is the appropriate management of vulvovaginal hematomas?

options.label: B
options.text: To prevent infection, they should all undergo ultrasound guided drainage

options.label: C
options.text: In a small hematoma, if pain is severe then ice packs and analgesia are appropriate

options.label: D
options.text: If bleeding ceases, small to moderate-sized hematomas can be treated expectantly.

questions.correct_answer: D. If bleeding ceases, small to moderate-sized hematomas can be treated expectantly.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) If bleeding ceases, small to moderate-sized hematomas can be treated expectantly.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the management of vulvovaginal hematomas , expectant management is appropriate for small to moderate-sized hematomas if bleeding has ceased and there is no significant pain or hemodynamic instability. Surgical intervention is reserved for large, expanding, or symptomatic hematomas.
  • ➤ vulvovaginal hematomas
  • ➤ small to moderate-sized hematomas
  • ➤ Surgical intervention

questions.text: Ligation at which of the following labeled vessel points in the retroperitoneum will decrease the pulse pressure in the uterine artery?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) B

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ligation of the anterior division of the internal iliac artery is crucial for managing postpartum hemorrhage by reducing uterine artery pulse pressure and controlling bleeding.
  • ➤ anterior division of the internal iliac artery
  • ➤ postpartum hemorrhage

questions.text: The following picture unfortunately depicts a maternal death after delivery. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Uterine inversion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Uterine inversion is a serious obstetric emergency where the uterus turns inside out, often resulting in neurogenic shock due to the traction on nerve plexuses.
  • ➤ Uterine inversion
  • ➤ neurogenic shock

questions.text: A 24y P2 is having atonic PPH following delivery. What is the name of this instrument used in the management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Bakri tube

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Bakri balloon is an essential instrument for the management of atonic PPH , used to control bleeding by exerting pressure inside the uterus. It is effective in stabilizing patients with severe hemorrhage by providing mechanical tamponade.
  • ➤ Bakri balloon
  • ➤ atonic PPH

questions.text: A 34-year-old G3P3 begins having brisk bright red bleeding following completion of a vaginal delivery. You consider giving her carboprost tromethamine. Which of the following is a contra-indication to this drug?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Bronchial asthma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Carboprost tromethamine (PGF2α) is contraindicated in patients with bronchial asthma due to the risk of bronchoconstriction. Always evaluate a patient’s medical history for asthma before administering carboprost for postpartum hemorrhage.
  • ➤ Carboprost tromethamine
  • ➤ bronchial asthma

questions.text: A 24-year-old G2P1 at 30 week’s gestation presents in the emergency after being found unconscious at home by her 10y old child. She is oriented on arrival and found to have a blood pressure of 180/110 mm Hg and 4+ proteinuria. Upon questioning she reports a history of eclampsia in her prior pregnancy at 34 week’s gestation. She again has a seizure which resolves with magnesium sulfate administration. Once the patient is stabilized, she undergoes cesarean delivery for malpresentation. The below magnetic resonance imaging was performed postpartum. What is the most likely finding on imaging?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Posterior Reversible Encephalopathy Syndrome (PRES) is commonly seen in conditions with severe hypertension , such as eclampsia or preeclampsia . It is characterized by hyperintense lesions on MRI, typically in the parietal and occipital lobes .
  • ➤ Posterior Reversible Encephalopathy Syndrome (PRES)
  • ➤ severe hypertension
  • ➤ eclampsia or preeclampsia
  • ➤ hyperintense lesions
  • ➤ parietal and occipital lobes

questions.text: The urine Congo red test has a high predictability in the identification of?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Pre-eclampsia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The urine Congo red test is a promising tool for the identification of pre-eclampsia through the detection of misfolded proteins in urine. It is especially valuable in low-resource settings due to its cost-effectiveness and ease of use, distinguishing it from other conventional urine tests.
  • ➤ urine Congo red test
  • ➤ identification of pre-eclampsia
  • ➤ misfolded proteins
  • ➤ low-resource settings

questions.text: A 27-year-old multigravida tells you at her 28-week prenatal care visit that she shows interest in a tubal ligation after delivery. For which of the following reasons do encourage her to get the procedure done?

options.label: A
options.text: It is associated with a later age of menopause

options.label: B
options.text: It is associated with a lower incidence of ovarian cancer

options.label: C
options.text: It is associated with a lower incidence of PID

options.label: D
options.text: It is associated with a lower incidence of PCOS

questions.correct_answer: B. It is associated with a lower incidence of ovarian cancer
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) It is associated with a lower incidence of ovarian cancer

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tubal ligation is associated with a reduced risk of ovarian cancer but does not influence menopause timing, PID incidence, or PCOS. It acts as a barrier that reduces the likelihood of exposure to potentially oncogenic substances, providing a protective effect against ovarian cancer.
  • ➤ Tubal ligation
  • ➤ reduced risk of ovarian cancer

questions.text: A 37-year-old underwent a bilateral tubal ligation 2 years ago at the time of her third cesarean section. She now presents with amenorrhea and nausea and vomiting for the last month. You perform a urine pregnancy test, and it is positive. You perform an ultrasound and discover the finding below at the right adnexa. It measures 4 cm and the beta hCG is 7000. What is the next best management option?
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of unruptured ectopic pregnancy with high beta-hCG levels (>5000 IU/L) and large mass size (>3.5 cm), surgical management is indicated. Laparoscopic salpingectomy is preferred for patients who have undergone tubal ligation to prevent future ectopic recurrence.
  • ➤ unruptured ectopic pregnancy
  • ➤ high beta-hCG levels
  • ➤ large mass size
  • ➤ surgical management
  • ➤ Laparoscopic salpingectomy
  • ➤ tubal ligation

questions.text: Identify the procedure as shown in the image below.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pomeroy's technique

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pomeroy's technique is a commonly used form of tubal ligation where a loop of the fallopian tube is formed, ligated, and then cut. This method is effective for permanent sterilization and is widely practiced.
  • ➤ Pomeroy's technique
  • ➤ tubal ligation

questions.text: Ms. M is a 24-year-old recently engaged woman who presents to discuss contraceptive methods in advance of her wedding. She and her fiancé have not been sexually active and do not intend to be until after the wedding. She has no medical comorbidities and has a normal body mass index. She has always had irregular menstrual cycles ranging from 28 to 40 days. She is sure that they do not desire pregnancy for 1 to 2 years, and she has a religious objection to any method that has prevention of implantation of a fertilized embryo as a major mechanism of action. Taking all these factors into account, what is the most efficacious method you can recommend for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Combined contraceptive pill

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The combined contraceptive pill is effective for women who wish to regulate their menstrual cycle and avoid pregnancy for a certain duration. It also aligns with religious concerns as it primarily works by preventing ovulation , not by preventing implantation.
  • ➤ combined contraceptive pill
  • ➤ preventing ovulation

questions.text: With use of the contraceptive method pictured, how frequently should it be replaced?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Weekly

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The contraceptive patch should be replaced weekly for three weeks, followed by one patch-free week. This method provides effective contraception without the need for daily administration.
  • ➤ contraceptive patch
  • ➤ weekly

questions.text: Ms. T calls complaining of dull lower abdominal pain for the last 2 months. You placed an intrauterine device (IUD) 3 months ago, and she has never attempted to palpate the strings. Her LMP was 2 weeks back. On speculum examination you see the picture below. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?

options.label: C
options.text: Attempt IUD removal by means of an IUD hook or long artery forceps

options.label: D
options.text: Continue the exam by twirling a cytologic brush in her endocervical canal

questions.correct_answer: A. Obtain a trans vaginal ultrasound
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When the IUD strings are missing and the patient experiences symptoms, the first step is to obtain a transvaginal ultrasound to determine the location of the IUD. This ensures the appropriate management of the IUD and avoids potential complications.
  • ➤ IUD strings are missing
  • ➤ obtain a transvaginal ultrasound

questions.text: A 19-year-old G1P1 complains of worsening vulvar pain in the recovery room 6 hours following a vaginal delivery. The delivery was complicated by a prolonged second stage and a third-degree laceration. On further evaluation, her temperature is 37.2 0 C, heart rate 130 beats per minute, blood pressure 86/52 mmHg, and respiratory rate 28 breaths per minute. She appears pale and distressed. Examination of the perineum reveals the findings shown in the pic below. What is the next best course of action?

options.label: B
options.text: Place a vaginal pack and Foley catheter

options.label: C
options.text: Check a complete blood count and observe closely

options.label: D
options.text: Start intravenous antibiotics with gram-negative coverage

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Urgent surgical evacuation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the case of a vulvar hematoma causing signs of shock , urgent surgical evacuation is required to control bleeding and stabilize the patient. Prompt intervention is crucial to prevent further hemodynamic compromise.
  • ➤ vulvar hematoma
  • ➤ shock
  • ➤ urgent surgical evacuation

questions.text: A 41-year-old G4P3 presents for fetal sonographic evaluation at 19 week’s gestation. The following image is obtained. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Anencephaly

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Anencephaly is characterized by the absence of the skull and most brain tissue , leading to the characteristic frog face appearance on ultrasound.
  • ➤ Anencephaly
  • ➤ absence of the skull and most brain tissue
  • ➤ frog face

questions.text: You are augmenting a term patient who is attempting a vaginal birth after cesarean delivery. She is 6 cm dilated, 90% effaced, and –1 station and was comfortable with her epidural anesthesia when you checked her 10 minutes ago. You notice the heart rate tracing abnormalities that are pictured. You recheck the patient, but can no longer feel the fetal head. The maternal heart rate is 85 beats per minute, blood pressure 84/46 mmHg, and respirations 18 breaths per minute. What is the best intervention based on the findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Proceed with emergency laparotomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of fetal bradycardia , maternal hypotension , and inability to palpate the fetal head during a VBAC , immediate emergency laparotomy is required to manage potential uterine rupture or dehiscence and ensure maternal and fetal safety.
  • ➤ fetal bradycardia
  • ➤ maternal hypotension
  • ➤ VBAC
  • ➤ emergency laparotomy
  • ➤ uterine rupture
  • ➤ dehiscence

questions.text: Identify this uterine incision shown in the image below:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Lower segment transverse

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The lower segment transverse (Kerr) incision is the preferred incision for cesarean sections due to its superior healing and reduced risk of complications in future pregnancies. It is important to differentiate between incision types, as the risks associated with each can vary.
  • ➤ lower segment transverse (Kerr) incision

questions.text: In all except which of the following presentations may forceps be used?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Mentum posterior

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Forceps may be used in face presentation with mentum anterior , occiput posterior , and occiput transverse presentations. However, they cannot be used in mentum posterior presentation, as this position does not have a mechanism for successful vaginal delivery and requires a cesarean section .
  • ➤ face presentation with mentum anterior
  • ➤ occiput posterior
  • ➤ occiput transverse
  • ➤ mentum posterior
  • ➤ cesarean section

questions.text: To resolve the complication shown in the image below, which of the following maneuvers should not be employed?

options.label: A
options.text: The fetus should be pulled downward to release the arm

options.label: B
options.text: The fetus should be rotated 180 degrees clockwise and then counter-clockwise

options.label: C
options.text: The fetus is gently pushed upward back into the pelvis for second attempt at rotation if a primary maneuver is unsuccessful

questions.correct_answer: B. The fetus should be rotated 180 degrees clockwise and then counter-clockwise
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) The fetus should be rotated 180 degrees clockwise and then counter-clockwise

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In breech deliveries involving nuchal arms, the Lövset maneuver should be employed. This maneuver involves rotating the fetus 180 degrees in each direction to safely release the arms and avoid complications.
  • ➤ Lövset maneuver

questions.text: Based on the ultrasound findings shown in the image of a pregnant woman, you suspect the genetic studies to show?

options.label: D
options.text: Any of the above could be seen

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 46 XX

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The snowstorm appearance on an ultrasound is indicative of a complete molar pregnancy , which is characterized by a karyotype of 46 XX due to duplication of paternal chromosomes.
  • ➤ snowstorm appearance
  • ➤ complete molar pregnancy
  • ➤ 46 XX

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the umbilical artery Doppler shown below?

options.label: C
options.text: This finding is normal until 32 week’s gestation

options.label: D
options.text: This pattern indicates decreased resistance to umbilical artery blood flow.

questions.correct_answer: B. This is reversed end-diastolic flow
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) This is reversed end-diastolic flow

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Reversed end-diastolic flow on an umbilical artery Doppler is a sign of severe placental insufficiency and fetal compromise, often requiring immediate intervention, especially after 34 weeks gestation.
  • ➤ Reversed end-diastolic flow
  • ➤ 34 weeks

questions.text: An anxious mother brings her 16y daughter to the gyn OPD. She is very concerned that she hasn’t yet got her period. On further questioning, she is active in her class and is in the school basketball team. On examination, her breasts are well developed as is her pubic and axillary hair. The external genitalia appear normal. She does not permit a vaginal exam. What is the next best step?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ultrasound

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a patient with primary amenorrhea and normal secondary sexual characteristics , the next best step is to perform an ultrasound to assess the presence and structure of the uterus and other internal reproductive organs.
  • ➤ primary amenorrhea
  • ➤ normal secondary sexual characteristics
  • ➤ ultrasound

questions.text: A 23y presents to the OPD with a concern that she is having a disturbance in the frequency of her menstrual cycles. A normal menstrual cycle has a frequency of?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 24 – 38 days

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The normal menstrual cycle frequency is now considered to be between 24 to 38 days .
  • ➤ normal menstrual cycle frequency
  • ➤ 24 to 38 days

questions.text: The patient pictured below presents complaining of the need to manually reduce the bulge by pushing her fingers inside the vagina every time she has to defecate—especially when she is constipated. Which is the procedure used to correct this defect?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Posterior colporrhaphy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a patient with symptoms of rectocele —such as the need to manually reduce a posterior vaginal bulge during defecation—the corrective procedure is posterior colporrhaphy .
  • ➤ rectocele
  • ➤ posterior colporrhaphy

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman has abnormal uterine bleeding. A transvaginal ultrasound reveals a 15-mm endometrial stripe and an 8-cm solid right adnexal mass. An office endometrial biopsy shows grade 1 endometrioid adenocarcinoma of the uterus. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Endometrial cancer metastatic to the ovary

options.label: D
options.text: Ovarian granulosa cell tumor and endometrial cancer

questions.correct_answer: D. Ovarian granulosa cell tumor and endometrial cancer
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Ovarian granulosa cell tumor and endometrial cancer

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ In postmenopausal women presenting with abnormal uterine bleeding and an adnexal mass , consider the possibility of an ovarian granulosa cell tumor . These tumors secrete estrogen, which can lead to endometrial hyperplasia or endometrial carcinoma .
  • ➤ abnormal uterine bleeding
  • ➤ adnexal mass
  • ➤ ovarian granulosa cell tumor
  • ➤ endometrial hyperplasia
  • ➤ endometrial carcinoma

questions.text: During a postpartum hysterectomy for intractable bleeding, a Heaney clamp is placed on the uterine artery near its insertion to the uterus. What is the relationship between the ureter and uterine artery at this point?

options.label: A
options.text: The ureter is 2 cm medial to the uterine artery at this location

options.label: B
options.text: The ureter is 2 cm medial to the uterine artery and crosses under it

options.label: C
options.text: The ureter is 2 cm lateral to the cervix and crosses over the uterine artery

options.label: D
options.text: The ureter is 2 cm lateral to the cervix and crosses under the uterine artery.

questions.correct_answer: D. The ureter is 2 cm lateral to the cervix and crosses under the uterine artery.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) The ureter is 2 cm lateral to the cervix and crosses under the uterine artery.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ During a postpartum hysterectomy , it is important to understand the anatomical relationship between the ureter and uterine artery . The ureter lies 2 cm lateral to the cervix and crosses under the uterine artery, which is a crucial detail to avoid ureteral injury during surgery.
  • ➤ postpartum hysterectomy
  • ➤ ureter
  • ➤ uterine artery
  • ➤ ureter
  • ➤ 2 cm lateral to the cervix
  • ➤ crosses under

questions.text: Which of the following arrows depicts where the uterosacral ligament is ligated during a type II radical hysterectomy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) B

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a type II radical hysterectomy , the uterosacral ligaments are ligated at an intermediate point (arrow B ), providing a balance between cancer control and preservation of function.
  • ➤ type II radical hysterectomy
  • ➤ uterosacral ligaments
  • ➤ B

questions.text: A 42-year-old multipara has negative screening Pap test and positive human papillomavirus (HPV) DNA test results. These were repeated 1 year later with the same results. She is a long-time cigarette smoker and has had six lifetime sexual partners. She has not had a new sexual partner for 7 years. What is her strongest risk factor for cervical cancer?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Persistent HPV infection

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The primary risk factor for cervical cancer is persistent HPV infection , especially with high-risk strains like HPV 16 and HPV 18 . Smoking and multiple sexual partners are contributing risk factors but are secondary to the presence of a persistent HPV infection.
  • ➤ cervical cancer
  • ➤ persistent HPV infection
  • ➤ HPV 16
  • ➤ HPV 18

questions.text: A 23y is undergoing a TVS in view of infertility. Which is not a possible cause of her infertility based on the image seen?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Anovulation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of a dominant follicle on ultrasound is a sign that ovulation is occurring. Anovulation can be ruled out as a cause of infertility when a mature follicle is identified, but other factors such as uterine abnormalities , tubal patency , or male infertility may still contribute to the infertility diagnosis.
  • ➤ dominant follicle
  • ➤ ovulation
  • ➤ Anovulation
  • ➤ uterine abnormalities
  • ➤ tubal patency
  • ➤ male infertility

questions.text: Which of the following serum hormone levels are most likely to increase after ovarian drilling?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ovarian drilling is a surgical treatment for women with PCOS and infertility that aims to normalize the hormonal profile by increasing FSH levels and decreasing LH and androgens (testosterone, androstenedione) , thereby promoting ovulation and improving fertility.
  • ➤ increasing FSH levels
  • ➤ decreasing LH and androgens (testosterone, androstenedione)

questions.text: Which of the following is the gold standard technique for tubal evaluation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Laparoscopic evaluation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The gold standard technique for tubal evaluation is laparoscopic chromotubation , which allows for direct visualization of the fallopian tubes and other pelvic organs, providing the most accurate diagnosis of tubal patency or abnormalities.
  • ➤ gold standard
  • ➤ laparoscopic chromotubation

questions.text: A 20-year-old nulligravida with a last menstrual period 5 days ago presents to the emergency department with generalized lower abdominal pain and fever. She reports a new sexual partner. Physical examination demonstrates guarding and bilateral adnexal fullness. Laboratory studies show leukocytosis, and transvaginal sonography reveals no visible ovaries but bilateral adnexal masses as shown here. The diagnosis most consistent with these findings is which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Tuboovarian abscess

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A tuboovarian abscess (TOA) is a complication of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) and presents with fever , lower abdominal pain , leukocytosis , and bilateral adnexal masses on imaging.
  • ➤ tuboovarian abscess (TOA)
  • ➤ fever
  • ➤ lower abdominal pain
  • ➤ leukocytosis
  • ➤ bilateral adnexal masses

questions.text: Symptoms of leiomyomas have been correctly partnered with the appropriate pathophysiology in all except which of the following pairs?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Asymptomatic—prolapsing fibroid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Prolapsing fibroids are typically symptomatic , presenting with bleeding and discomfort , not asymptomatic. In contrast, other symptoms of leiomyomas, such as menorrhagia (due to vascular changes), pelvic pressure (from compression), and acute pelvic pain (from degeneration), are linked to their respective pathophysiologies.
  • ➤ Prolapsing fibroids
  • ➤ symptomatic
  • ➤ bleeding
  • ➤ discomfort
  • ➤ menorrhagia
  • ➤ pelvic pressure
  • ➤ acute pelvic pain

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is listed by the manufacturer as a contraindication of this contraceptive method?

options.label: B
options.text: Heavy menses due to coagulation disorder

options.label: D
options.text: Uterine anomaly with distortion of the uterine cavity

questions.correct_answer: D. Uterine anomaly with distortion of the uterine cavity
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Uterine anomaly with distortion of the uterine cavity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The LNG-IUD should not be inserted in patients with a uterine anomaly that distorts the uterine cavity due to the increased risk of improper placement and failure of the device.
  • ➤ LNG-IUD
  • ➤ uterine anomaly that distorts the uterine cavity

questions.text: What is the lifespan of this newly introduced contraceptive advice?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 3 y

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Implanon NXT is a progesterone-only implant that is effective for 3 years and provides rapid return to fertility after removal. It is a reliable, long-acting contraceptive option for women seeking long-term, reversible contraception.
  • ➤ Implanon NXT
  • ➤ progesterone-only implant
  • ➤ 3 years

questions.text: What is the typical range of normal vaginal pH in a 25y old woman?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 4.0 to 4.5

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The normal vaginal pH for women in their reproductive years is typically between 4.0 and 4.5 , maintaining an acidic environment that helps protect against infections.
  • ➤ normal vaginal pH
  • ➤ 4.0 and 4.5

questions.text: Your 32-year-old patient has no complaints when presenting for a routine health maintenance visit but is found to have a clinically abnormal vaginal discharge during speculum examination of the vagina. A saline preparation of vaginal secretions demonstrates the motile pathogens shown here and marked by arrows. Your patient is at highest concurrent risk for which of the following?

options.label: D
options.text: Coinfection with other sexually transmitted pathogens

questions.correct_answer: D. Coinfection with other sexually transmitted pathogens
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Coinfection with other sexually transmitted pathogens

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Trichomoniasis is a sexually transmitted infection caused by Trichomonas vaginalis and is associated with an increased risk of coinfection with other sexually transmitted pathogens , such as chlamydia and gonorrhea .
  • ➤ Trichomoniasis
  • ➤ Trichomonas vaginalis
  • ➤ coinfection with other sexually transmitted pathogens
  • ➤ chlamydia
  • ➤ gonorrhea
